newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait to start futures trading on stock exchange.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait to start futures trading on stock exchange.

text.p: Kuwait has approved futures trading on its stock exchange only by investment portfolio managing institutions, officials said on Tuesday.
But they told Reuters that actual futures trading will not start immediately.
"A decree has permitted futures trading but actual trading will take place at a later stage," said one official refusing to give a target date.
The decree issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry stipulates that only institutions licensed to manage portfolios can carry out futures trade deals, he said.

They also should have a paid-up capital of no less than five million dinars ($16.7 million), said the official, noting that they need to hand regular reports on their financial position to the exchange.
The decree also says interested firms should acquire permission from the Central Bank and that their applications should be approved by the exchange.
Institutions licenced to deal in futures will not be allowed to place their own shares on that market, the decree published in this week's official gazette said.
Officials said the Kuwait Stock Exchange plans to issue further technical guidelines to govern futures trading.
Officials see the move as a profitable expansion of business but critics want the exchange to set tough controls to avoid dangerous uncontrolled speculation.
In 1982 an unofficial exchange crashed, resulting in tens of billions of dollars in losses and debts.
Officials have said futures trading will run for six months on a trial basis after which a fully fledged futures market could be launched in the oil-rich state.

The exchange has been riding high for several weeks. The index and trading volume and value have been setting almost weekly records in recent months during the short 2-1/2-hour trading sessions five days a week. On Monday, the index closed at 1,901.7 points, almost a 40 percent rise so far this year.

Only nationals of Gulf Arab states -- Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Kuwait -- can trade on the exchange. Foreign residents can invest through mutual funds ran by local firms.
Kuwait is considering opening trade for foreign investors.
